'''Barahir''' was a [[Gondorian]] of the [[Fourth Age]].
==History==
Barahir was the grandson of the [[Steward]] [[Faramir]], [[Prince of Ithilien]], and Lady [[Éowyn]] of [[Rohan]].<ref name=prologue/> He was likely named after [[Barahir|a famed hero]] of the [[First Age]], the father of [[Beren]], and/or [[Barahir (Steward of Gondor)|one of his ancestors]] who had served as [[Ruling Steward]] in the [[Third Age]].

Barahir flourished during the second century of the [[Fourth Age]] and after the death of [[Kings of Gondor|King]] [[Aragorn II Elessar]] he authored ''[[The Tale of Aragorn and Arwen]]''.<ref name=prologue/> 

His work survived in abbreviated form in the [[Thain's Book]].<ref name="prologue">{{FR|Records}}, p. 15</ref> 

==Etymology==
''Barahir'' is a [[Sindarin]] word and consists of ''[[bara]]'' ("fiery; eager") + ''[[hîr]]'' ("master, lord").<ref>{{LR|Etymologies}}, pp. 351, 364</ref>
